statement.tex: \text{A card from a pack of 52 playing cards}\\ \text{is lost. From the remaining cards of the}\\ \text{pack, three cards are drawn at random}\\ \text{(without replacement) and are found to be}\\ \text{all spades. Find the probability of the}\\ \text{lost card being a spade.}

\\ \textbf{What probability do we need to find?}\\ \text{Use the event definitions given below.}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Event} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline L & \text{The card lost is a spade.} \\ S_3 & \text{Three spades are drawn.} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\\ \text{Given that } \\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Event} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline L & \text{The card lost was a spade}\\ \hline \bar{L} & \text{The card lost was not a spade}\\ \hline C_N & \text{N-th card drawn is a spade.} \\ \hline \end{tabular}\\ \text{is the table below correct?}
\\ \textbf{Putting it all together.}\\ \text{Is the work done below correct?}

reason.tex: \text{We don't know that the lost card is a spade.}\\ \text{That is why we are finding the probability.}\\ \textbf{But }\text{we do know that three spades have}\\ \text{been drawn. Hence, we need to start thinking }\\ \text{about conditional probability - the condition }\\ \text{being that }S_3\text{ has occurred. Or, }P(L\vert S_3).

\text{Once a card is lost, we would either have}\\ \text{12 spades remaining or 13 spades. }\\ \text{It is then that we start drawing three cards.}\\ \textbf{Remember, }P(C_N\vert\, L)\text{ is the probability that}\\ \text{the N-th card drawn is a spade }\textbf{given that}\\ \text{the card lost was a spade.}\\ \textbf{Similarly, }P(C_N\vert\,\bar{L})\text{ is the probability that}\\ \text{the N-th card drawn is a spade }\textbf{given that}\\ \text{the card lost was }\textbf{not}\text{ a spade.}

\text{The event }S_3\text{ we defined in Step 1 is really}\\ \quad S_3 = C_1\cap C_2\cap C_3.\\ \text{Hence, we must multiply the probabilities.}\\ \textbf{But }\text{the probabilities we listed in Step 2}\\ \text{were }\textbf{conditional}\text{ probabilities.} \\ \text{Hence, it is not }P(S_3)\text{ that we know, but }\\ \mathbf{P(S_3\vert L)}\text{ and }\mathbf{P(S_3\vert\bar{L}).}

\text{In the formula below,}\\ \begin{align} P(L\vert S_3) &= \underbrace{\dfrac{P(S_3\vert L)\cdot P(L)} {P(S_3\vert L)\cdot P(L) + P(S_3\vert \bar{L})\cdot P(\bar{L})}}_{\text{Bayes' Theorem}} \end{align} \\ \text{we know }P(S_3\vert L)\text{ and }P(S_3\vert\bar{L}).\\ \text{But we do not know what }P(L)\text{ and }P(\bar{L})\text{ are.}\\ \text{So, remind yourself what event L is.}\\ \text{It is the event that the lost card is a spade.}\\ \text{So, if a card is lost from a full deck, then the}\\ \text{probability that it is a spade is} \\ \quad P(L) = \dfrac{13}{52} = \dfrac{1}{4}\implies P(\bar{L}) = \dfrac{3}{4}.
